subject: Re: Detecting failure in tearDown()
msgSnippet: I agree that this will work but I d prefer not to put the onus on every test author to remember to set the magic cleanUp flag. I m going to experiment with my
messageBody:
I agree that this will work but I'd prefer not to put the onus on
every test author to remember to set the magic cleanUp flag.

I'm going to experiment with my own TestRunner that simply overrides
these methods:

public void addError(Test test, Throwable t);
public void addFailure(Test test, AssertionFailedError t);

I'll let you know how it goes.

Thanks!

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Frohnhofer, Jim" <jfrohnhofer@u...>
wrote:
> In a similar, but simpler version of a previous poster, is there
anything
> wrong (philosophically or technically) with the following class?
>
> public MyTest extends TestCase {
> private boolean cleanUp;
>
> MyTest(String s) {
> super(s);
> }
>
> public void setUp() {
> cleanUp = false;
> }
>
> public void testSomething() throws Exception {
> /*
> *
> * Some code + assertions
> *
> *
> * And after every assertion has passed . . .
> */
>
> cleanUp = true;
> }
>
> public void tearDown() {
> if (cleanUp) {
> // do it
> }
> }
> }
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@r...]

> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Detecting failure in tearDown()
>
>
> jlindwall wrote:
>
> > I'd like to be able to determine in tearDown() whether or not the
> > test succeeded (eg, success, fail, or error).
> >
> > If you're curious why: If the test failed I'd like to leave the
> > database in it's current state to assist in manually determining
what
> > went wrong. If the test succeeded I'd like to cleanu p the db.
> >
> > Using the standard runner I don't see any way to do this. Do I
have
> > to subclass the runners to add this feature?
>
> Either subclass the test runner or, if you know any AOP, use an
aspect
> to do it. You're changing the behavior of runBare(), so I don't see
any
> alternative that doesn't lead to massive duplication.
>
> Good luck.
